acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since it was suggested that relevant toxicity is not indicated within the water solubility (insolubility (CERI/NITE Hazard Assessment Report (preliminary version) (2006)) of this substance in spite of 48 hours EC50>100mg/L of the crustacea (Daphnia magna) (IUCLID (2000) and others), it was classified into Not classified.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) value of >=5,000mg/kg ((ECETOC TR33 (1989)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category K by NTP (2005), Category A1 by ACGIH (2001) and Group 1 by IARC (1990).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: May cause long lasting harmful effects to aquatic life
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since although acute toxicity is not reported within the aqueous solubility concentrations, it was a metallic compound, and  the underwater action was unknown, it was classified into Category 4.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: There is no available data on heritable mutagenicity and in vivo germ cell mutagenicity /genotoxicity, whereas two data are available on in vivo somatic cell mutagenicity; one showed positive result (chromosome aberration/study on lymphocytes from exposed workers; however, this data is considered insufficient. (ECETOC TR33, 1989)), the other showed negative result (peripheral blood micronucleus tests on mice /90 days inhalation exposure)(NTP CB (Access on Mar., 2006), IARC 49 (1990), ATSDR (2005), ECETOC TR33 (1989). Although nickel has been known to possess a genotoxic potential (ATSDR, 2005), available data are considered insufficient to serve as a basis for classification as "Category 2" or "Not classified" with respect to mutagenicity defined in the GHS, since epidemiological data is not conclusive and animal data is negative. Therefore the substance has been classified as "classification is not possible".

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though inorganic compounds containing oxygen

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

respiratory_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause allergy or asthma symptoms or breathing difficulties if inhaled
respiratory_sensitizer.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as a Respiratory Sensitizing Substance by DFG and "Respiratory Sensitizing Substance: Group 2" (as nickel compounds) according to the Recommendation on Occupational Exposure Limits for Chemical Substances (Japan Society for Occupational Health (2005)).

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

skin_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
skin_sensitizer.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as a Skin Sensitizing Substance by DFG and "Skin Sensitizing Substance: Group 1" (as nickel compounds) according to the Recommendation on Occupational Exposure Limits for Chemical Substances (Japan Society for Occupational Health (2005)).

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (respiratory system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale:
Based on the human evidence including "pulmonary impairment, typical pneumoconiosis" (EHC 108 (1991)) and the evidence from animal studies including "granulomatous inflammation, hyperplasia of the bronchi/mediastinal lymph node," "alveolar wall thickening" (ATSDR (2005)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1. 
Chronic exposure to nickel and its compounds may produce respiratory irritation and degeneration in humans even at doses close to occupational exposure limits. Prolonged exposure to high concentrations is likely to result in the fibroid lung (ECETOC TR33 (1989)).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale:
No data available
The acute toxicity of nickel compounds manifests in humans as "nausea, diarrhea, dizziness, headache" (ECETOC TR33 (1989)).
